abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was
            satisfactory, with a likely sustainability, but with modest
            institutional development impact. Lessons convey that the
            Bank could have taken a more realistic approach regarding
            the level of adjustment Moldova was being forced to make in
            restoring economic growth, by addressing longer-term, and
            deeper-structural adjustments in the definition of project
            objectives. Hence, the agreed measures led to significant
            reduction of program effectiveness, conducive to extended
            implementation delays. Instead, front-loading conditionality
            prior to Board presentation, or the use of single tranche
            operations, could have been useful tools under circumstances
            of intense resource constraints, as is the case of Moldova.
            Furthermore, the inability to coordinate foreign assistance,
            should be guided by the Bank's assistance in donor
            coordination. Regardless of success, the privatization
            program as a whole, was not sufficiently deep, neither was
            the agricultural privatization - which seemingly, only
            provided a means of subsistence to the rural population.
            Therefore it is worth considering the privatization process
            early on, focused on post-privatization market development
            for agriculture, and, on the need for strong political will
            regarding industrial privatization.
